content.$t: poet: Stephanie Cawley, biography: Stephanie Cawley is a poet in Philadelphia. She is the author of My Heart But Not My Heart, winner of the Slope Book Prize chosen by Solmaz Sharif, and the chapbook A Wilderness from Gazing Grain Press. Her poems and other writing appear in DIAGRAM, The Fanzine, TYPO, The Boston Review, and West Branch, among other places. Her next book Animal Mineral will be out from YesYes Books in 2022., website: https://stephaniecawley.com//, instagram: https://www.instagram.com/stephanie__cawley, twitter: https://twitter.com/_s_cawley, profileimage: https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/5f1cb0d99322d817a05021ad/6b9e1bc1-7e16-4c9d-9761-cb92c2c6a040/Cawley_Stephanie.jpg

gsx$biography.$t: Stephanie Cawley is a poet in Philadelphia. She is the author of My Heart But Not My Heart, winner of the Slope Book Prize chosen by Solmaz Sharif, and the chapbook A Wilderness from Gazing Grain Press. Her poems and other writing appear in DIAGRAM, The Fanzine, TYPO, The Boston Review, and West Branch, among other places. Her next book Animal Mineral will be out from YesYes Books in 2022.

content.$t: poet: Cynthia Dewi Oka, biography: Cynthia Dewi Oka is the author of Fire Is Not a Country, forthcoming in fall 2021 from Northwestern University Press (NUP), Salvage: Poems (NUP, 2017) and Nomad of Salt and Hard Water (Thread Makes Blanket, 2016). The recipient of the Tupelo Quarterly Poetry Prize and the Leeway Transformation Award, her writing has appeared in The Atlantic, POETRY, Academy of American Poets, The Rumpus, PANK, Guernica, and elsewhere. She has taught creative writing at Bryn Mawr College and is a 2021-2022 Amy Clampitt Resident. She is the creator of Sanctuary: A Migrant Poetry Workshop for immigrant poets based in Philadelphia, and is originally from Bali, Indonesia., website: http://www.cynthiadewioka.com, facebook: https://www.facebook.com/sindewi, instagram: https://www.instagram.com/freedewi/, twitter: https://twitter.com/freedewi, profileimage: https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/5f1cb0d99322d817a05021ad/83dd6a1a-4d79-41b9-9695-58d96fa50a94/Cynthia_Dewi_Oka_-_Photo_by_Jose_Quintana.JPG_Photo_by_Jose_Quintana.JPG

gsx$biography.$t: Cynthia Dewi Oka is the author of Fire Is Not a Country, forthcoming in fall 2021 from Northwestern University Press (NUP), Salvage: Poems (NUP, 2017) and Nomad of Salt and Hard Water (Thread Makes Blanket, 2016). The recipient of the Tupelo Quarterly Poetry Prize and the Leeway Transformation Award, her writing has appeared in The Atlantic, POETRY, Academy of American Poets, The Rumpus, PANK, Guernica, and elsewhere. She has taught creative writing at Bryn Mawr College and is a 2021-2022 Amy Clampitt Resident. She is the creator of Sanctuary: A Migrant Poetry Workshop for immigrant poets based in Philadelphia, and is originally from Bali, Indonesia.

content.$t: poet: Emari DiGiorgio, biography: Emari DiGiorgio is the author of Girl Torpedo and The Things a Body Might Become. She's the recipient of the Auburn Witness Poetry Prize, the Ellen La Forge Memorial Poetry Prize, the Elinor Benedict Poetry Prize, the NJ Poetry Prize, RHINO's Founder's Prize, and a poetry fellowship from the New Jersey State Council on the Arts. Emari is the Faculty Director of Murphy Writing of Stockton University, where she teaches first-year writing and poetry and serves as President of the Stockton Federation of Teachers, AFT 2275., website: https://www.emaridigiorgio.com/, facebook: https://www.facebook.com/emari.digiorgio, instagram: https://www.instagram.com/emari_digiorgio/, twitter: https://twitter.com/Emari_DiGiorgio, profileimage: https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/5f1cb0d99322d817a05021ad/4255611e-cbec-47f6-a2ef-fee96196b5c8/DiGiorgio_Emari.jpg

gsx$biography.$t: Emari DiGiorgio is the author of Girl Torpedo and The Things a Body Might Become. She's the recipient of the Auburn Witness Poetry Prize, the Ellen La Forge Memorial Poetry Prize, the Elinor Benedict Poetry Prize, the NJ Poetry Prize, RHINO's Founder's Prize, and a poetry fellowship from the New Jersey State Council on the Arts. Emari is the Faculty Director of Murphy Writing of Stockton University, where she teaches first-year writing and poetry and serves as President of the Stockton Federation of Teachers, AFT 2275.

content.$t: poet: Anna Evans, biography: Anna M. Evans' poems have appeared in the Harvard Review, Atlanta Review, Rattle, American Arts Quarterly, and 32 Poems. She gained her MFA from Bennington College. Recipient of Fellowships from the MacDowell Artists' Colony and the Virginia Center for the Creative Arts, and winner of the 2012 Rattle Poetry Prize Readers' Choice Award, she currently teaches at West Windsor Art Center and Rowan College at Burlington County. Her books include her latest chapbooks, The Quarantina Chronicles (Barefoot Muse Press, 2020) and The Unacknowledged Legislator (Empty Chair Press, 2019), along with Under Dark Waters: Surviving the Titanic (Able Muse Press, 2018), and her sonnet collection, Sisters & Courtesans (White Violet Press, 2014)., website: http://annamevans.com, facebook: https://www.facebook.com/evnsanna, instagram: https://instagram.com/evnsanna, twitter: https://twitter.com/Barefoot_Muse, profileimage: https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/5f1cb0d99322d817a05021ad/c2e3ae1c-8308-4cb8-9b26-d97ea7ecfe9f/Evans_Anna.jpg

gsx$biography.$t: Anna M. Evans' poems have appeared in the Harvard Review, Atlanta Review, Rattle, American Arts Quarterly, and 32 Poems. She gained her MFA from Bennington College. Recipient of Fellowships from the MacDowell Artists' Colony and the Virginia Center for the Creative Arts, and winner of the 2012 Rattle Poetry Prize Readers' Choice Award, she currently teaches at West Windsor Art Center and Rowan College at Burlington County. Her books include her latest chapbooks, The Quarantina Chronicles (Barefoot Muse Press, 2020) and The Unacknowledged Legislator (Empty Chair Press, 2019), along with Under Dark Waters: Surviving the Titanic (Able Muse Press, 2018), and her sonnet collection, Sisters & Courtesans (White Violet Press, 2014).

content.$t: poet: Todd Evans, biography: Todd is the host and founder of two of the longest running open mic in Burlington and Mercer Counties. Mr. Evans is also an author and founder of The Don Evans Players community theater group (named after his late father, a playwright). Todd is a married proud grandfather of three., facebook: https://www.facebook.com/Books-by-Todd-C-C-Evans-101597458694150/, profileimage: https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/5f1cb0d99322d817a05021ad/94f06fe2-50d9-4ec4-8edb-6dae0b7eee83/Evans_Todd.jpg

gsx$biography.$t: Todd is the host and founder of two of the longest running open mic in Burlington and Mercer Counties. Mr. Evans is also an author and founder of The Don Evans Players community theater group (named after his late father, a playwright). Todd is a married proud grandfather of three.

content.$t: poet: Shawn Jones, biography: Shawn R. Jones is the co-owner of Tailored Tutoring LLC and Kumbaya Academy, Inc. She is the author of two poetry chapbooks, A Hole to Breathe (2015) and Womb Rain (finalist in the New Women’s Voices Series 2008). Her work has appeared or is forthcoming in TriQuarterly, New Ohio Review, Rattle, River Heron Review, Guesthouse, and elsewhere. Her manuscript was a semi-finalist for the Antivenom Poetry Award and finalist for the Saturnalia Books contest. She holds an MFA from Rutgers-Camden and has been nominated for the Pushcart Prize. When she is not writing or teaching, she enjoys dancing and spending time with her family and lucky pit bull, Ross., website: http://shawnrjones.com, facebook: https://www.Facebook.com/srj.writer, instagram: https://www.Instagram.com/poet.srj/, twitter: http://Twitter.com/ShawnRJones1, profileimage: https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/5f1cb0d99322d817a05021ad/6141c09a-54e5-4399-a0ae-1ad645ced8c5/Jones_Shawn.jpeg

gsx$biography.$t: Shawn R. Jones is the co-owner of Tailored Tutoring LLC and Kumbaya Academy, Inc. She is the author of two poetry chapbooks, A Hole to Breathe (2015) and Womb Rain (finalist in the New Women’s Voices Series 2008). Her work has appeared or is forthcoming in TriQuarterly, New Ohio Review, Rattle, River Heron Review, Guesthouse, and elsewhere. Her manuscript was a semi-finalist for the Antivenom Poetry Award and finalist for the Saturnalia Books contest. She holds an MFA from Rutgers-Camden and has been nominated for the Pushcart Prize. When she is not writing or teaching, she enjoys dancing and spending time with her family and lucky pit bull, Ross.

content.$t: poet: Rogan Kelly, biography: Rogan Kelly is the author of Demolition in the Tropics (Seven Kitchens Press, 2019). His work has appeared, or is forthcoming, in New Orleans Review, The Penn Review, Plume, RHINO, and elsewhere. He is the editor of The Night Heron Barks and Ran Off With the Star Bassoon., website: https://rogankelly.wordpress.com/, facebook: https://www.facebook.com/rogan.kelly.5, instagram: https://www.instagram.com/jerzypoet/, twitter: https://twitter.com/JerzyPoet, profileimage: https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/5f1cb0d99322d817a05021ad/a1b3a40d-6093-4c7f-aa01-809d9c1b8fd1/Kelly.JPG

gsx$biography.$t: Rogan Kelly is the author of Demolition in the Tropics (Seven Kitchens Press, 2019). His work has appeared, or is forthcoming, in New Orleans Review, The Penn Review, Plume, RHINO, and elsewhere. He is the editor of The Night Heron Barks and Ran Off With the Star Bassoon.

content.$t: poet: Peter Murphy, biography: Peter E. Murphy was born in Wales and grew up in New York where he managed a night club, operated heavy equipment and drove a taxi. Author of 11 books and chapbooks of poetry and prose, his work has appeared in The Common, Diode, Guernica, Hippocampus, The New Welsh Review, Rattle, and elsewhere. He is the founder of Murphy Writing of Stockton University., website: http://www.peteremurphy.com, facebook: http://www.facebook.com/peter.e.murphy, instagram: http://www.instagram.com/murphywriting, twitter: https://twitter.com/murphywriting, profileimage: https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/5f1cb0d99322d817a05021ad/314d5c2f-3018-419a-8ec0-457716d2f766/Murphy_Peter.jpg, notes: http://www.murphywriting.com

gsx$biography.$t: Peter E. Murphy was born in Wales and grew up in New York where he managed a night club, operated heavy equipment and drove a taxi. Author of 11 books and chapbooks of poetry and prose, his work has appeared in The Common, Diode, Guernica, Hippocampus, The New Welsh Review, Rattle, and elsewhere. He is the founder of Murphy Writing of Stockton University.

content.$t: poet: Kathleen Volk Miller, biography: Kathleen Volk Miller has written for LitHub, NYT Modern Love, O, the Oprah magazine, Salon, the New York Times, Huffington Post, Washington Post, Family Circle, Philadelphia Magazine and other venues. "How We Want to Live," an essay, was chosen as the penultimate piece in Oprah's Book of Starting Over (Flat Iron Books, Hearst Publications, 2016). She is co-editor of the anthology, Humor: A Reader for Writers (Oxford University Press, 2014). She is co-editor of The Painted Bride Quarterly and co-host of PBQ's podcast, Slush Pile. She has also published in literary magazines, such as Drunken Boat, Opium, and other venues. She holds "Healing through Writing" workshops, and other memoir classes. She consults on literary magazine start up, working with college students, and getting published in literary magazines. She is a professor at Drexel University., website: www.kathleenvolkmiller.com, facebook: https://www.facebook.com/painted.quarterly, instagram: https://www.instagram.com/kvm1303/, twitter: https://twitter.com/PaintedBrideQ, profileimage: https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/5f1cb0d99322d817a05021ad/719d15ed-a999-46be-a673-a93ad99f34a9/Volk-Miller_Kathleen.jpg

gsx$biography.$t: Kathleen Volk Miller has written for LitHub, NYT Modern Love, O, the Oprah magazine, Salon, the New York Times, Huffington Post, Washington Post, Family Circle, Philadelphia Magazine and other venues. "How We Want to Live," an essay, was chosen as the penultimate piece in Oprah's Book of Starting Over (Flat Iron Books, Hearst Publications, 2016). She is co-editor of the anthology, Humor: A Reader for Writers (Oxford University Press, 2014). She is co-editor of The Painted Bride Quarterly and co-host of PBQ's podcast, Slush Pile. She has also published in literary magazines, such as Drunken Boat, Opium, and other venues. She holds "Healing through Writing" workshops, and other memoir classes. She consults on literary magazine start up, working with college students, and getting published in literary magazines. She is a professor at Drexel University.

content.$t: poet: BJ Ward, biography: BJ Ward’s poems have appeared in Poetry, American Poetry Review, TriQuarterly, The New York Times, and The Sun, among others, and have been featured on NPR’s “The Writer’s Almanac,” NJTV’s “State of the Arts,” and websites such as Poetry Daily and Vox Populi. He is the recipient of a Pushcart Prize and two Distinguished Artist Fellowships from the New Jersey State Council on the Arts. His most recent book is Jackleg Opera (North Atlantic Books/Random House), which received the Paterson Award for Literary Excellence)., website: https://www.bj-ward.com, profileimage: https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/5f1cb0d99322d817a05021ad/a105d78b-8e6b-44b6-899f-3d993eaae899/BJ_Ward.jpg

gsx$biography.$t: BJ Ward’s poems have appeared in Poetry, American Poetry Review, TriQuarterly, The New York Times, and The Sun, among others, and have been featured on NPR’s “The Writer’s Almanac,” NJTV’s “State of the Arts,” and websites such as Poetry Daily and Vox Populi. He is the recipient of a Pushcart Prize and two Distinguished Artist Fellowships from the New Jersey State Council on the Arts. His most recent book is Jackleg Opera (North Atlantic Books/Random House), which received the Paterson Award for Literary Excellence).
